content: Wow! I found this one quite challenging to solve. I have now solved it in C#, and will vote to approve. If it's approved, I expect the number of users who solve it will be very low. For me, this was the most difficult community puzzle I have completed to date. Nice puzzle.

Very nice. My grandfather used to have an electronic game that did this. I had hours of fun with it as a kid.

I have made some minor edits for grammar, and I added an example to the Statement. Hopefully it clarifies things a bit. Unfortunately, the asterisks look kind of funny in the example because they "hover" above the dots, at least in my browser. I kept it that way to go with the test format, though.

I will try to solve the puzzle later. Thanks for an interesting submission.

Thanks for your grammar corrections ; I’m not an english native speaker ^^

Weird for the asterisks, I tried with Safari, Firefox and Chrome ; I can’t try with IE or Edge :/
Thats a pity, it is the perfect character for a lit LED ^^

You were right ; six after two days, including us, that’s quite low! It seems that all the current published solutions work with the first line brut force ; not surprising considering the mathematical way involves an N^2 x N^2 matrix :D

I noticed that my solution's significantly different from everyone else's, though. I wasn't able to get the 15x15 fast enough in C#. I'm sure it's possible, but I decided to take a different tactic that is based on the "follow the lights" strategy. It does a double pass in which the first pass is trivial, but then the pattern for the second pass can maybe take a long time to compute, but in every example I've tried, it finds the solution quite early in the computation process. I don't know enough about to math to prove whether this will always be the case or not.

I still think about this one, and have downloaded a lights-out app for my phone to play with it when I have spare time. Thanks again. :-)

Yep, I saw you had a two pass strategy, and was a bit curious about that ^^
Here is a bit of maths : http://mathworld.wolfram.com/LightsOutPuzzle.html ; it’s a big linear system of N^2 equations in Z2 ; it can work with several cycling colors if you move to Zn :)
http://www.ueda.info.waseda.ac.jp/~n-kato/lightsout/

I like it. It shares way too much code with the last one I solved, but that's hardly your fault.

I don't think the asterisk alignment is too much of an issue, but you could always consider alternatives like 01 and xo.

It's good to go as is as far as I'm concerned. The evil within me ponders adding a red herring in the lines of "find THE quickest way to..."

Thanks ^^

Well, for the asterisk, I’ll let the moderators do what they want if they publish it :)

I wouldn’t dare for "find THE quickest way", as I’m not sure my own solution is the most optimized :D

[Edit] I’m now sure it isn't, as I was told there is a polynomial (N^6 ?) mathematical algorithm to solve this, when my (more simple) solution is in O( (N^2)×(2^N) ) :)
It's still the quickest way in terms of button presses, as the soluiton is unique, and pressing any button more than once is redundant.

Oh, I see, from clicking point of view ^^ I avoided multi-solutions cases for the purposes of simplicity, but it may be more interesting to put several-solutions cases and ask for the "quickest" one :)

The meaning of my initial evil comment was more in a "the problem ought to be set up so that solutions are unique" way,  so that "quickest" really is a red herring.

Haven't had the time to validate my math on how to actually prove it so, will get to it later if the problem didn't get validated in the meantime.
